title: Identify the Weak Assumption
prompt: The project failed because the team added three new hires. Which assumption is the weakest?
options: The project had no other issues.
explanation: Assuming that new hires always reduce productivity is a hasty generalization.

title: Correlation vs Causation
prompt: After a new marketing campaign, sales increased. Which conclusion is most rigorous?
options: The campaign definitely caused the increase.
The campaign might have contributed, but other factors could be involved.
explanation: Recognizing alternative explanations is better than claiming certainty.

title: Generalization Test
prompt: You meet three people from a company and all three are very direct. Which statement is most reasonable?
options: Everyone at that company is rude.
Everyone at that company is direct.
Many people at that company might be direct, but you need more data.
Their directness proves the culture is toxic.
explanation: Extrapolating from three cases to 'many' with uncertainty is more careful than 'everyone'.

title: Competing Hypotheses
prompt: A product launch failed. You have two hypotheses: H1: price too high. H2: poor messaging. You have data showing many people visited the page but abandoned at checkout. Which hypothesis does this support more?
explanation: Abandoning at checkout suggests interest but resistance at the point of payment, pointing to price or fees.

title: Fallacy: Ad Hominem
prompt: "You can ignore her argument about climate policy; she never finished college." What is the main fallacy?
explanation: Attacking the person instead of engaging with the argument is ad hominem.

title: Base Rate Neglect
prompt: A rare disease affects 1 in 10,000 people. A test is 99% accurate. A random person tests positive. What is the best interpretation?
options: They almost certainly have the disease.
They almost certainly do not have the disease.
It is still unlikely they have the disease; the base rate is extremely low.
explanation: Ignoring the base rate leads to overestimating the probability after a positive test.

title: Necessary vs Sufficient
prompt: Having a ticket is ______ to enter a concert.
options: both necessary and sufficient in most cases
explanation: Normally you must have a ticket and having it allows entry (ignoring rare exceptions).

title: Hidden Variable
prompt: Ice cream sales and drownings both increase in summer. This suggests:
explanation: Temperature is a hidden variable influencing both.

title: Steelman vs Strawman
prompt: Your colleague slightly exaggerates your argument and attacks the exaggerated version. This is:
explanation: Attacking a distorted version of the argument is a strawman.

title: Causal Graph Intuition
prompt: You notice: more training hours → better sales performance, but only in teams with good managers. Which model fits best?
options: Training directly causes performance, independent of management.
Management quality moderates the effect of training.
explanation: The effect of training depends on management quality, a moderator.

title: One-Sentence Problem
prompt: Describe a current problem in a single, precise sentence. Avoid buzzwords and vague terms.
explanation: Forcing yourself into one sentence exposes vagueness and missing structure.

title: Break It into 3 Sub-Problems
prompt: Take the problem you just described. Break it into exactly three smaller sub-problems that, if solved, would largely solve the whole.
explanation: Decomposition is central to structured thinking and reduces overwhelm.

title: Define Success
prompt: For one of your current projects, write down what 'success' actually means in measurable or observable terms.
explanation: Many cognitive failures come from unclear goals.

title: Assumptions vs Facts List
prompt: Write two short lists: (1) facts you are confident about, (2) assumptions you are making about the situation.
explanation: Making assumptions explicit helps you challenge and refine them.

title: Stakeholders and Incentives
prompt: List the key stakeholders in your situation and what each one actually wants.
explanation: Clarity often comes from understanding incentives and constraints.

title: Invert the Problem
prompt: Instead of asking 'How do we achieve X?', ask 'If we wanted to guarantee failure, what would we do?' List 3–5 actions.
explanation: Inversion reveals hidden failure modes and clarifies strategy.

title: What Would Change Your Mind?
prompt: Pick a belief you hold about a project or decision. Write which piece of evidence would genuinely change your mind.
explanation: Defining 'update triggers' improves epistemic humility and clarity.

title: Constraints vs Preferences
prompt: List three constraints that truly cannot be changed, and three preferences that you could relax if needed.
explanation: Separating absolute constraints from preferences opens new options.

title: Time vs Money Trade-off
prompt: You can pay €300 to save 5 hours of work, or do it yourself. Your effective hourly rate is about €80. Which choice is more rational financially?
options: Do it yourself to save cash now.
explanation: 5 hours at €80 is €400 in value; paying €300 is cheaper than spending your own time.

title: Expected Value Intuition
prompt: Option A: 70% chance to gain €1,000. Option B: guaranteed €600. Which has higher expected value?

title: Three Options Only
prompt: For a real decision you face, write down exactly three realistic options and one clear upside/downside for each.
explanation: Explicit options force comparison instead of vague worrying.

title: Act / Wait / Investigate
prompt: For your current decision, classify what you should do next: act now, wait intentionally, or gather more information. Justify your choice in 2–3 sentences.
explanation: Separating these three moves reduces indecision and panic action.

title: Sunk Cost Trap
prompt: You've invested 200 hours into a project that clearly has low traction. You feel you 'can't quit now or the time is wasted.' What bias is this?
explanation: Sunk cost = letting past investments dictate current decisions.

title: Regret Minimization
prompt: You are choosing between a safe job and a startup opportunity. You imagine yourself in 10 years. Which question is most useful?
options: Which choice looks better on my CV next year?
Which choice would I regret more *not* trying?
Which choice matches what my friends recommend?
Which choice feels less scary today?
explanation: Regret-minimization over a long horizon helps align with deep preferences.

title: Define the Worst-Case
prompt: For a decision you are postponing, write down the realistic worst-case outcome and how you would handle it.
explanation: Making the worst-case explicit often reduces vague fear.

title: Asymmetric Upside
prompt: Identify one option in your current decision that has small downside but large possible upside. Describe it in 2–3 lines.
explanation: Asymmetric bets are central to good strategic decision-making.

title: Confirmation Bias
prompt: You only read articles that support your current opinion on a topic. Which bias is this?
explanation: Seeking only confirming evidence is confirmation bias.

title: Availability Bias
prompt: You overestimate the risk of plane crashes because you recently saw one in the news. Which bias?
explanation: Recent vivid events dominate perception of probability.

title: Halo Effect
prompt: You assume someone is good at everything because they are charismatic and successful in one domain. Which bias?
explanation: Halo effect = one positive trait spills over into others.

title: Framing Effect
prompt: People prefer a treatment with '90% survival' over one with '10% mortality', although they are identical. Which bias?
explanation: Different framing of the same numbers changes perception.

title: Gambler's Fallacy
prompt: A coin has landed on heads 6 times in a row. Someone says: 'Tails is now due.' Which bias?
explanation: Each flip is independent; past flips don't change probabilities.

title: Loss Aversion
prompt: You reject a 50/50 bet to win €200 or lose €100. Which bias shapes this reaction?
explanation: Losses hurt more than equivalent gains feel good.

title: Status Quo Bias
prompt: You stick to a bad supplier just because 'we've always used them.' Which bias?
explanation: Preference for the current state even when better options exist.

title: Bias Self-Scan
prompt: Think of a recent decision you regret. Identify one bias that likely influenced you and write how you would counter it next time.
explanation: Meta-awareness converts abstract bias knowledge into practical skill.

title: Odd One Out – Objects
prompt: Pick the item that does NOT belong.
explanation: Three are animals; one is an object.

title: Pattern Snap
prompt: Which number continues the sequence? 2, 4, 8, 16, ?
explanation: The pattern is ×2 each time.

title: Quick Category
prompt: What category best describes: 'keyboard, mouse, monitor'?
explanation: Fast categorization is a System 1 skill.

title: Instant Plausibility
prompt: Which sentence sounds more plausible as a headline?
options: Company doubles revenue in one week with no new customers.
Company grows revenue 15% over a quarter after launching a new offer.
explanation: Fast plausibility checks matter in noisy information environments.

title: Quick Fallacy Tag
prompt: "Everyone successful wakes up at 5am. If you wake up at 5am, you'll be successful." This is closest to:
explanation: It reverses cause and effect: success may drive habits, not the other way.

title: Synonym Snap
prompt: Pick the closest synonym for 'concise'.
explanation: Fast verbal associations train linguistic intuition.

title: Risk Intuition
prompt: Which risk is generally higher in everyday life?
explanation: Helps recalibrate intuitive risk perception.

title: Simple Proportion
prompt: Which is larger?
explanation: Fast approximate math is part of intuitive thinking.

title: System 2 Activation
prompt: Pick an important decision. In 4–6 sentences, describe the context, your options, and why this decision actually matters long term.
explanation: Simply writing context and stakes activates deliberate thinking.

title: Evidence Inventory
prompt: List the strongest *for* and *against* pieces of evidence for your preferred option. Aim for at least three on each side.
explanation: Slow thinking requires weighing both confirming and disconfirming data.

title: Alternative Stories
prompt: Write two plausible alternative explanations for the same set of facts. How would each change your action?
explanation: Considering multiple narratives improves cognitive flexibility.

title: Long-Term vs Short-Term
prompt: For a current choice, list the short-term incentives and long-term incentives. Which dimension are you over-weighting?
explanation: Slow thinking balances present comfort with future payoff.

title: Steelman Opposing View
prompt: Write the strongest version of the argument against your current opinion on a topic. Do it as if you wanted that argument to win.
explanation: Steelman practice reduces dogmatism and strengthens reasoning.

title: First Principles Breakdown
prompt: Take a belief like 'This is too expensive.' Break it into first principles: what are you really optimizing for (value, risk, time, alternatives)?
explanation: First principles thinking decomposes vague judgments into primitives.

title: Meta-Decision
prompt: Describe how you usually make big decisions. What is one change you could make to your process to reduce regret?
explanation: Thinking about how you think (metacognition) is core to System 2 training.

title: Moral/Philosophical Reflection
prompt: Pick a value that guides your life (e.g., autonomy, fairness). Write how it influences one major decision you are considering.
explanation: Linking values to concrete choices deepens philosophical reasoning.

title: Implication
prompt: If all A are B and all B are C, which statement must be true?
explanation: Transitivity: A → B and B → C implies A → C.

title: Contrapositive
prompt: The contrapositive of 'If it rains, the ground is wet' is:
options: If the ground is wet, it rained.
If the ground is not wet, it did not rain.
If it does not rain, the ground is not wet.
If the ground is not wet, it might not have rained.
explanation: Contrapositive of P→Q is ¬Q→¬P.

title: Only One True
prompt:
Exactly one of the following statements is true:
A) B is true.
B) C is false.
C) A is false.
Which statement is true?
explanation: If C is true, then A is false and B is true (since C is false), giving two truths; check combinations to see C is the only consistent one.

title: Truth-Tellers
prompt: In a group, truth-tellers always tell the truth, liars always lie. Alex says: 'Ben is a liar.' Ben says: 'Chris is a liar.' Chris says: 'Alex and I are the same type.' Who is the truth-teller?
explanation: Working through assignments shows only Chris can consistently be a truth-teller.

title: Minimal Inference
prompt: From 'Some engineers are designers' you can infer:
explanation: If some engineers are designers, then some designers are engineers.

title: Set Intersection
prompt: All A are B. Some B are not A. Which diagram fits?
options: A is inside B; B has extra parts.
B is inside A; A has extra parts.
A and B do not overlap.
explanation: A subset B with extra elements: classic Venn structure.

title: Impossible Condition
prompt: If 'All cats are dogs' and 'Some cats are not dogs' are both stated, what can you say?
explanation: Universal inclusion contradicts existence of a counterexample.

title: Necessary Condition
prompt: To legally drive, you must have a valid license. Which is true?
options: Having a license is sufficient but not necessary.
Having a license is necessary but not sufficient.
Having a license is neither necessary nor sufficient.
Having a license guarantees you are a good driver.
explanation: You must have a license, but that alone does not guarantee skill.

title: Alternative Uses
prompt: List as many non-standard uses as you can for a paperclip in 60–90 seconds.
explanation: Classic divergent thinking drill: fluency and originality.

title: Constraint Remix
prompt: Take a product or service you know well. Imagine it must work with a zero marketing budget. List 3 creative ways it could still grow.
explanation: Creativity likes constraints; they force unusual paths.

title: Opposite Day
prompt: Pick a habit or process. Imagine you had to do the exact opposite for one week. Describe what would happen and what you would learn.
explanation: Inversion stimulates new perspectives and breaks patterns.

title: Analogy Engine
prompt: Take a current challenge and find an analogy from sports, nature, or engineering. Explain how that analogy helps you see the problem differently.
explanation: Analogical thinking is a core creative mechanism.

title: Future Scenario
prompt: Imagine your field 10 years from now. Describe three changes that would surprise most people today.
explanation: Future thinking expands the space of possibilities.

title: Combine Two Domains
prompt: Pick two unrelated domains (e.g., fitness and finance). Brainstorm a product or idea that meaningfully combines them.
explanation: Combining domains is a reliable path to novel ideas.

title: Remove a Constraint
prompt: Describe your project assuming one big constraint suddenly disappears (e.g., budget, time, tech limit). What would you do differently?
explanation: Temporarily suspending constraints reveals hidden options.

title: Philosophical Reframe
prompt: Take something you see as a 'problem' and reframe it as a 'training ground' or 'signal'. Write how that changes your approach.
explanation: High-level reframing fuses creativity with philosophical reasoning.

title: Number Logic Sprint
prompt: Find the next number: 2, 6, 12, 20, ?

title: Letter Pattern Flash
prompt: Complete: A, C, F, J, ?

title: Quick Sequence
prompt: What comes next: 1, 4, 9, 16, ?

title: Pattern Recognition
prompt: Next in series: 3, 6, 11, 18, ?

title: Double Step Logic
prompt: Find pattern: 2, 3, 5, 8, 12, ?

title: Prime Jump
prompt: Next prime: 2, 3, 5, 7, 11, ?

title: Geometric Growth
prompt: Complete: 2, 4, 8, 16, ?

title: Analogy Flash: Animals
prompt: Bird : Nest :: Bear : ?

title: Analogy Flash: Objects
prompt: Pen : Writer :: Brush : ?

title: Analogy Flash: Actions
prompt: Run : Marathon :: Swim : ?

title: Analogy Flash: Abstract
prompt: Chaos : Order :: Noise : ?

title: Analogy Flash: Science
prompt: Atom : Molecule :: Cell : ?

title: Analogy Flash: Concepts
prompt: Input : Output :: Question : ?

title: Analogy Flash: Opposites
prompt: Hot : Cold :: Light : ?

title: Analogy Flash: Process
prompt: Seed : Tree :: Idea : ?

title: Analogy Flash: Tools
prompt: Hammer : Nail :: Screwdriver : ?

title: Analogy Flash: Systems
prompt: Code : Software :: Blueprint : ?

title: Pattern Complete: Shapes
prompt: Triangle, Square, Pentagon, ?

title: Pattern Complete: Colors
prompt: Red, Orange, Yellow, ?

title: Pattern Complete: Reverse
prompt: Z, X, V, T, ?

title: Odd Logic: Numbers
prompt: Which doesn't belong: 2, 4, 7, 8, 10?

title: Odd Logic: Words
prompt: Which doesn't fit: Apple, Banana, Carrot, Orange?

title: Odd Logic: Concepts
prompt: Which is different: Run, Walk, Sit, Jump?

title: Odd Logic: Patterns
prompt: Which breaks the pattern: 3, 6, 9, 11, 15?

title: Odd Logic: Primes
prompt: Which isn't prime: 7, 11, 13, 15, 17?

title: Odd Logic: Shapes
prompt: Which differs: Circle, Oval, Square, Ellipse?

title: Odd Logic: Abstract
prompt: Which doesn't match: Growth, Expansion, Contraction, Increase?

title: Odd Logic: Pairs
prompt: Which pair differs: 2-4, 3-6, 4-8, 5-11?

title: Odd Logic: Sequence
prompt: Which breaks: AB, CD, EF, GI, JK?

title: Category Flash: Living
prompt: Quick: Is 'coral' living or non-living?

title: Category Flash: Science
prompt: Quick: Is 'gravity' a force or matter?

title: Category Flash: Logic
prompt: Quick: Is 'all A are B' same as 'all B are A'?

title: Category Flash: Numbers
prompt: Quick: Is 91 prime or composite?

title: Category Flash: Fallacy
prompt: Quick: 'Everyone does it' - valid or fallacy?

title: Category Flash: Cause
prompt: Quick: Correlation implies causation - true or false?

title: Category Flash: Sets
prompt: Quick: If A⊂B and B⊂C, then A⊂C - valid?

title: Category Flash: Probability
prompt: Quick: P(A and B) can exceed P(A) - true or false?

title: Category Flash: Negation
prompt: Quick: Opposite of 'all cats are black' is?

title: Category Flash: Inference
prompt: Quick: If no A are B, are some B not A?
